160960653.review:
This is, without a doubt, my favorite game of all time. The vibe of this ocean world is just so pleasant, it's become the perfect place to go to get away from real life for me. Sure, there's drowning and sea monsters, but they're easier to deal with than rent and bills. Prevent the one, dodge the other. Simple. Life's real simple on the ocean world. 

...also it's a great exploration survival game with a satisfying tech tree as you build up your ability to go farther and deeper to gather more unique resources to build your next upgrade, as you work your way not towards infinite growth or any sort of material wealth, but simply to make a way back home. Every new area you reach is fascinating and fun to explore, every new plant animal or mineral you see is well designed and fits well in an interconnected ecosystem, and the various smaller mysteries and optional discoveries spread around the planet are compelling and make for great replay content.

You should play Subnautica. Unless you've got like a crippling phobia of the deep sea or large things in the sea. In that case Subnautica might not be the game for you. But for everyone else, you should really play Subnautica. If you really like it, like I do, the sequel's good too.

158159644.review:
Everyone who knows me will know that I despise most open-world games for both narrative and gameplay reasons - they are often open-world for no reason at all other than to artificially prolong a player's playtime with the dreadful "collectibles" (ugh).

How do you make a good open-world game then? Look no further than Subnautica. I like the fact that you are never explicitly told by the game to "go here, do this" to fulfil quest objectives unlike most open-world games. It just drops hints here and there and it's up to you to follow up on the main story. You are also subtly discouraged from staying in the same area due to the need to scavenge for food and resources, forcing you to explore. Despite being open-world and never having a hard limit to areas, the game cleverly blocks off access to those areas in the early stage by requiring you to craft items first. There is no hard boundary of the map either - the spooky atmosphere at the soft boundary of the map is enough to force you to return. Every little detail in the game design is so subtle and well thought out.

In any game, film and book, the first thing I look for is atmosphere. I cannot praise the atmosphere in this game enough. On an alien planet without a map, every step you take is full of danger. The feeling of isolation, powerlessness and fear of the unknown, make this game the scariest game that's not actually designed to be a horror game.

I have high standards and this is one of the few games that I am hard-pressed to find faults in... That tells you enough about it. 10/10

160506733.review:
After playing Subnautica for 40-odd hours, I was all set to give it a thumbs-down - after all, there's a lot in there not to like:

* A quite annoying UI: buttons that do different things depending on the context, containers you can't move or deconstruct without emptying them, no way to move anything you've created once you've created it other than breaking it down and doing it over... It actually made me think of another game I've played recently - an early-access title called Forever Skies that I thought was really poor for many of the same reasons.

* Practically no direction - after 40 hours, I still only had a pretty vague idea of what I was trying to achieve.

* Strange game balance - useful things (like the Alien Containment) that you can't get until long after the time when they're no longer very useful to you (I had the full blueprint for the Cyclops and the Nuclear Reactor long before I could find any fragments for the Alien Containment).

* Really unsatisfying weaponry... I mean, it's a world where everything is trying to eat you, crush you or electrocute you, and the best you've got for a lot of it is a knife?!? Even later on when you get torpedoes, the stasis rifle and so on, they're not actually much use or much fun.

... and so on. But then I actually sat and thought about it, and realized that I just don't like survival games very much. Looking at it from that perspective, I could see that this is actually a pretty good game for its genre - the fact that I don't really like the genre isn't its fault.

So I'm going to give it a thumbs up, mostly because I can see how people who like this style of game would really enjoy it, and because the things that were good (like base building, the scenery, the music and the atmospherics) were actually *really* good.

I doubt I'll bother trying to finish it or play it again, though.

163125155.review:
[b]My Score:[/b] 9,5/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
The oceans, since ancient times, have been sources of beauty, riches and inspiration for great adventures and stories, but also a source of danger and fear, especially of what may be swimming in the depths and which we may not even know about, as well represented by countless legends. and myths about creatures that live beneath the waves. Nowadays with the exploration of the oceans, we know that even with its dangers there is no colossal being lurking, but what would happen if this certainty was thrown away, when diving into the waters of an alien ocean, full of unknown wonders and dangers. ^^

This is what the protagonist of our story will discover in the most brutal way and without warning possible, a simple employee of the Aurora transport ship on another day like any other at work. Until the moment that without any warning the ship is hit by something that causes the entire crew to be evacuated, with our protagonist escaping alone in one of the escape capsules, after a "slight" head injury, he leaves the capsule and observes who stands alone, with only the ocean of an unknown planet stretching everywhere he looks. ^^

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ A survival game with an extensive map, full of different environments, each with its own resources and creatures to explore and discover.
+ The game has an entire ecosystem, with animals and plants that inhabit certain environments and depths, and can be analyzed to discover more about them.
+ Wide variety of resources that can be collected for production, from the simplest equipment to the most advanced and futuristic.
+ Option to build a base, not only to be a safe place, but also useful during the journey.
+ A very interesting story with some twists, which progresses according to the player's exploration pace.
+ For those who wish, in addition to the classic option, there is an option without having to worry about hunger and thirst, and a creative option.
+ Beautiful graphics, it really seems to be a world under the waters of an alien ocean.
+ Excellent soundtrack and sound work in creating the vocalization of all the creatures.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- If you don't have Thalassophobia, the fear of the ocean, be prepared to feel the sensation a little as the creatures will give you a lot of scares during your first encounters.
- Some very rare bugs, like one time I saw a large creature enter the ground and never come out, and another time I took damage when touching a peaceful one.

[h1] Game mechanics[/h1]
After the "soft" start of escaping from the burning ship, our exploration begins, deciding where to swim in search of resources, if the objective is just to stay alive, the clear waters close to the surface are fully capable of supplying everything necessary, but If you want to go beyond survival and escape from this planet you will need to go deep, very deep in search of new resources that will release new equipment, however some are too advanced but fortunately Aurora had several useful equipment for underwater exploration, which first need to be analyzed as they became just fragments with the explosion, analyzed by undoubtedly one of the most useful tools of all, the scanner that allows not only to analyze the fragments, but also the ores and life forms on the planet. ^^

This is a very important point, as it will be an exploration without the presence of any other human being, with the only company being the varied and colorful life forms native to the planet, forms that have evolved to live perfectly beneath the waves, some peaceful. who won't care about the player, others will attack but only to defend their territory, and some are carnivores and will love to try the taste of the flesh of the only human on the planet. But as we explore the depths, we discover that not everything is in perfect balance on this planet, and that something is disturbing the ecosystem and will try to put the player on its endless list of victims. ^^

[h1] Art and sound[/h1]
Produced by the Unknown Worlds Entertainment studio, I only have praise for the graphics, they did very well in creating each unique biome, each creature adapted to living in the conditions of the depth in which it lives and the notion for the player of how the depth increases as the waters become more and more darker and sinister. The soundtrack part was also impeccable, the songs are great, matching each biome and the great work in creating the sounds of the various creatures, especially underwater the sound reaches much further than the light, so there are several moments that we hear the creatures before we even see them. ^^

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
Subnautica was a curious case for me because I never really liked the idea of exploring deep, dark waters, even in games, and yet for some reason I bought this game when it was still in the early stages of Early Access. And so over the years I started the game, but I stopped when I started to have to go deeper, until finally at the beginning of this year I stopped messing around and finally finished this great game, which now I can say that even despite the scares and despite a little stress sometimes not finding the right resource or fragment, this is a very fun game, and I recommend it to everyone who likes a good exploration game and a good story. ^^

161905611.review:
You crash land on an alien world, your mighty spaceship burning in the near distance, and there from the lone safety of your escape pod does the boundless ocean stretch infinitely before you in all directions. Only it doesn't, there are actually a couple of land masses *right there*, you just can't see them because of the draw distance. Because when a game has more imagination than budget it has to hide things from you-- a genre epitomized by Subnautica. It's not bad, it's even great up until the point where you inevitably notice the smoke and mirrors, but all the "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews should be tempered by a few critical ones. I didn't finish this game, because it's empty and repetitive and it stopped being fun.

Subnautica can be distilled down to "there's no map." There desperately needs to be a map, but there isn't, because if there were you'd know where to go, and the absolute bulk of the gameplay is derived from not knowing where to go. The bulk of the gameplay is stumbling across things and then trying to find them again later, searching half-remembered areas for caves and accidentally going 1km in the wrong direction and being lost-- being lost is what this game IS. And that's fine, that's an experience, I often LOVE that experience in a game, but not in this one, because you also have to collect resources and everything you need is in specific places and a map would sure help but there isn't one. If there were a map it would be a short, repetitive game with a map. As it is, it's a long, repetitive game with no map. And I get it, to fill a huge game and an ocean with Things takes a huge budget, but not everyone who can imagine a huge game will have the budget for one and so you get this genre of game where it looks big and feels big but isn't big. It's not fair, but it's how it is. And eventually people will start using AI to fill that emptiness their games instead of just limiting their focus and it will be bad in a different way.

Subnautica is, eventually, bad because, like similar limited-budget open-world games, if you strip out the text and audio logs then all you have is the same set of art assets arranged in slightly different ways across a large area. How many unique areas or objects are in this game? I can think of... five? Six? And the rest is just the same section of crashed ship with the same wreckage strewn about and the same kind of items and the same underwater caves and the same hazards and the same rewards, and the world is great, it's impressive, it's the right world to create when you have limitations because all fish are the same, but you need gameplay that's more than collecting the same resources from the same places to build things that let you do that same thing but slightly faster. With no map. Strip out the text and audio logs and you get a game that desperately needs text and audio logs to carry the narrative. And the text and audio is good, and Tom Jubert should write more games instead of other writers because he's better than most other writers, but aside from some very limited environmental storytelling his work is not *part* of the world, it's added-in on top of it. 

I got sick of collecting minerals from the same unmapped areas and eating the same fish and so I used the text and audio logs to draw my own meaning out of this game. So much of that text and audio is just human interpersonal BS and inanity and materialism that is contrasted so heavily by the beautiful natural environment you've become a part of-- I mean there you are at sea in the sun listening to Some Jerk distractedly mention rescue information while he talks to someone else about his sandwich order, and you're just thinking... "THIS is what I want to go back to?" Why would anyone want to be "rescued" from this planet, empty as it is, when the alternative is being plugged back into Human Society. I don't know if this contrast is on purpose because I didn't finish the game's story because I didn't want to collect any more damned rocks-- I just decided my character was staying, and uninstalled the game. 

He lives there now, on the water planet. I don't know if that was going to be an option at the end of the game, but there was no need to wait so I made it an option. He, at least, is free from a world that creates games and things like Subnautica-- superficial things and bad draw distances to conceal from you from how little it's possible to have when imagination is free but nothing else is.

163318234.review:
Possibly one of the best games I've ever played, and this is as a latecomer in 2024. I went into this game blind on the recommendations of almost every game reviewer, and I was immediately immersed in the world. The game itself doesn't really give you much instruction, so it leans into the idea that you're all alone on an alien planet with only your own personal resourcefulness. I genuinely felt like I was a bit lost, trying to figure out the rules of this game/world, afraid to leave the starting lifepod, jumping at every shadow or sound. Just a truly immersive experience is all I can say.

The graphics aren't RDR2 quality, but they somehow feel more real than a lot of newer games. I often find myself just swimming around admiring the underwater landscape. The music is incredible, matching the mood and biomes with relaxing, chill vibes at times or heart-pumping terror at others.

There are also a variety of mods available to enhance and extend gameplay after you finish the vanilla game, so I expect my 430+ hours to continue well past 1000.

[h1] Subnautica: 100% COMPLETION REVIEW [/h1]

[hr][/hr]
[code][b]If you love completing games, take a look at our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44890520/]curator site. [/url][/b][/code]

[hr][/hr]
Subnautica is a fantastic game that does a really good job at maintaining the perfect atmosphere at all parts of the game. It makes you truly feel the wonder of exploring a beautiful new location, or the terror and dread of navigating a dangerous area. Being open-world, the game will rarely force you to follow the main story, but the story arc is compelling enough that you will want to complete it, and you will be almost sorry when it's all over. This is one of the best survival / exploration games of all time, and an absolute must-play.

As for the achievements, all but one of them are story-related. Though they can technically be missed before you end the game, it would be rather difficult to miss them on a blind playthrough, as they correspond to each of the locations that the game suggests you to head towards next. For the last achievement, "Hatch and release a Cuddlefish", there is a guide to help you find one of five Cuddlefish egg locations in the map.

163253730.review:
Subnautica is an awesome game that made every hour spent on it worth it. Exploring the deep sea not knowing what to expect and being shit scared reaching the deeper areas was definitely a  memorable experience. I could spent whole day playing it and not getting enough of it. 
This game offers a variety of new blueprints that unlocks new base parts, new equipment, new vehicles that are very fun to use and other stuff. There is always something to look for so you wont get bored plus the mechanic of starving and dehydration makes you looking for food and water all the time so it adds to the survival experience because Subnautica is a mix of survival, exploring, horror and even building. But in my opinion the machanic of running out of oxygen (because we are 90% of the time in the water) is something that adds to the gameplay and makes it more challenging, you need to watch out for it because if you are very deep under water and you are running out of it the only option is to swim to the surface or hop on your vehicle and I need to admit I have many situatiuons that I died because I couldn't find a way out of a cave or I wasn't fast enough to get to the surface.
Speaking of caves Subnautica has a very large map with a lot of biome variety in it, which some of them are really creepy like that one biome that has that white kelps and a bloody oil growing on it. I also really like how Subnatica made a map boarder that is actually diffrent and unique, its like a void where the only thing you  will find Is a big glowing creatures.... I even one entered it didn't nowing that its a void and there is nothing to looking for in it and that makes it so unique.
When it comes to exploring the underwaters we have vehicles like:seaglide that you can fit in your inventory and helps you swim faster, seamoth that is a small vehicle that enables you to use modifications like:solar, torpeds and electrical pulse which deters some predators away and you can shoot torpeds out of it, PRAWN suit that anables you to mine ores, has arms that are good in dealing damage , enables fast travel when you have modification which makes your are shote a kind of a rope, and a biggest vehicle on this list:Cyclops that is a full blown titanic-like underwater ship its very satisfactional to unlock its blueprint and finally make it.
I still didn't tell about a big variety of fishes and the BIG fishes that you can meet upon your journey. The categories for the fishes are:the small fishes that are usually harmless, medium fishes and most of them(maybe not most but) are predators like that teleporting one or the long fast one. The last category is leviathans, some of them are not hostile to the player and some will just want to eat you and destroy your vehicle. Usually the more friendly ones are near the capsule area when you first "spawn" in and the more dangerous one are in the deeper areas which is pretty logical and obvious.
I finally wanna talk about a story of Subnautica that can be really deep. The story comes in found PDA's across the map and in massages that you hear from the radio that are transmitted beetwen a certain time periods, you cal always read this massages later like PDA's once you hear them/found them.
Also tip: when you scan objects you can get a lot of useful info so I advise you to scan evetything you can.
In conclusion I think Subnautica is a game that is really worth recommending and giving it a try, this game isn't even very expensive to buy so it is a big plus and it is worth buying right away without waiting for a discount (of course you can wait because this game gets discout very often but I just wanted to say it is very worth its price).
Final rating:10/10

162238889.review:
I was hesitant to try Subnautica for years due to my agoraphobia and experience with other underwater games like Endless Ocean. However, after a friend gifted it to me I knew I'd have to set aside my fears and give it a try. As it turns out, I had quite a lot of fun -- but also a few [i]very[/i] tense moments with particularly dangerous situations and limited visibility.

By and large, if you can stay within sight of the sea floor or cliff sides it can help with feeling anxious or "lost". The lifeboat you start in is also very close to the center of the map and it's icon can help tremendously as a general waypoint. The surface of the world is pretty much water, but the Aurora in the distance can help a [i]lot[/i] with finding your bearings, as well, when you come up for air. Although I'll be honest that getting anywhere near it often fills me with a sense of dread, but that's probably related to the agoraphobia so who knows. :D

The plethora of sea life and various plants are breathtaking and also something neat to scan if you get the chance, there's tons of stuff to catalogue as you play and the descriptions range from amusing to thoughtful. Most of the things you can craft are learned by scanning objects found in wrecks, so always be on the lookout for something unfamiliar. [i]Also[/i] make sure you check every data cache for possible new constructs or tools, like a new kind of wetsuit or an augment for your vehicles!

If I had to knock the game for anything it would probably be the [i]over[/i] aggression of certain creatures. Some are attracted to the very lights your vehicle uses to keep you from being basically blind, as some areas are far too dark for their own good. Fumbling in the dark isn't as fun when you have 360 move space and limited air or battery life. It can be super disappointing to leave your Seamoth for a moment to grab or investigate, turn around and a monster has taken it or destroyed it and left you stranded and likely dead in the water as a result.

The other main issue is inventory space. Most tools take a single spot, but others like the stungun and seaglide take large sections. You can also find dufflebags which.. you [i]can not[/i] pick up if they have stuff in them?? Makes them effectively useless. I also found having to go back and forth so often due to space limitations on the frustrating side as the game went on and I would need more and more things. Making multiple trips can feel exhausting or repetitive depending on the situation.

Otherwise, the game was a whole lot of fun and I'm so grateful to my friend for giving me the chance to experience it.

161744535.review:
Not even finished yet and I can confidently state that this is one of the best games I have ever played.  I'm an avid scuba diver and I must say, they got so many underwater elements correct when it comes to the lighting, the sounds, the clarity and/or particulates in the water, the immersion - it just feels like you're there.  Slap on some headphones and play in the dark... give it a try - hope you don't startle easily.  I mean, you are much more nimble in the water than anyone every should/could be, but hey, can't be fully realistic and that's not the goal.  This isn't a diving simulator.

I originally didn't play this game as it was labelled as "survival horror".  I like neither of those categories - I don't like survival games and I don't play horror games.  This game squarely falls in neither of these categories, but has some overlapping elements.  This is the right blend and mix for what I find is basically a world and story exploration game with survival and "scary" and "intimidating" elements.

What was not expected with this game was how compelling it is to continue to play and explore.  It's literally so addictive I can hardly think of anything else when I start getting into it.  I completely lose myself in this game.  This is what I want in a gaming experience...

The progression is exemplary.  Just when you think you've crafted or found something that will take you to a new opportunity or to the "next level", you're immediately slapped back into your place of being out of place in this huge and vast alien nautical world.  Just when I feel slighly more capable, more brave, and more willing to venture into further darkness and unknown, the overwhelming feeling of not being prepared enough or underskilled/powered to be where I've ended up becomes apparent.  There's always some story element causing you some stress and pressure to continue to keep going - without it there wouldn't have been nearly the atmosphere and feeling of necessity and purpose as it's constantly undermined by your need to survive.  What a great blend of priorities amalgamated together.

I'm not the greatest or most coherent review writer, but I will also say that the music in this game really is top notch and adds to the experience.  It comes and goes away in almost a scripted fashion with what you're experiencing, and it's so well matched and themed to this game I just can't say enough about how this improves the experience.

And last but not least, the graphics.  I'm playing this 5-6 years after release, with max settings on a beast gaming PC.  It looks phenomenal.  Not exactly lifelike/realistic, but in it's style, it sure feels like it.  I've tried the game in VR, and that is truly the immersive experience, but the controls are still a bit hard to use, and any misclick or time wasted while crafting/building, or when you're in a panic and about to drown or being attacked by some unknown creature, not a good experience.  But if you want immersion and a more realistic experience, I highly recommend at least trying (I used the Index with the index controller/hands mod) it, and I fully intend to just do some exploring in VR and not bother with technical elements like the big crafting component.  I didn't find the crafting onerous in this game, it was actually a lot of fun exploring and trying to find new materials and fabrications to make the next best thing.  I've built a library of catalogued storage cabinets and basically have acquired and taken back scores of everything to my underwater alchemy base.  Try saying you've had that experience in any other game...

So in summary, this game is unique, creative, well executed, super immersive, ultra fun, and just makes you want to keep playing and playing.  Couldn't recommend highly enough.

158828294.review:
I heard about this game from the Outer Wilds community and gave it a shot. It's different -- instead of lore/mystery it leans much more heavily into survival. This was a drag at first, and I almost put it down. 

I'm glad I stuck with it though. The game does a phenomenal job of making you feel like you're diving/exploring underwater reefs and caves.

The cave-diving aspect in particular felt extremely tense. You glance to your oxygen counting down, so you turn around to head back -- and realize you're lost.
The way out never looks the same as the way in.
Suddenly your heart is beating like crazy, and you're trying not to panic. Surely the way out is just ahead. Wait that's a dead-end, that can't be right..
That oxygen you have sure is going down quickly. Was this cave really worth it?

...Definitely confirmed for me that I'm never going cave diving in my life, regular scuba was enough for me. Can't believe how disorienting those caves/wrecks are.

Game's good though

157150389.review:
Subnautica, or how-I-developed-a-fear-of-water simulator is a brilliant game. I need to preface my review by saying that I bought this game in the earliest of access, back in 2014. Despite of this, it took me 10 years to write a review. Honestly, I feel shame that I have been this lazy... 

With that out of the way: Get this game. It is probably my favorite game to replay, as the world Unknown Worlds has created here is just absolutely amazing. Not only that, but it's not a cheap horror game. Nope, this game feeds on your fear, kinda like a terror game. Basically, you are always feeling vulnerable, and unless you do not dodge the... Larger creatures, you are pretty much always "safe". Of course, there are other dangers, like radiation early-mid game, small piranha-like fish and leech-like worms to name a few. But that feeling of not being safe you get when you dive into it, even when you take your small sub (Seamoth) for a ride, or even the larger Cyclops is just... Amazing. Now of course, if you have thalassophobia, you might wanna rethink getting this game, as 97% of the game occurs in the vast ocean world of 4546B. Although, maybe you can conquer said fear if you get the game...?

Uknown Worlds are great developers. The game runs amazingly, I am getting 142 FPS on high with my PC (Ryzen 7 7700X and RX 7800XT). Optimization like this is awesome to see, and I imagine it must have been hard as your PC has to render so many fish swimming around, and a plethora of different biomes etc. Even on a weaker PC, expect to play on medium-ish graphics with at least 60 FPS, if not higher. 

The story is amazing. It ties in to Unknown Worlds' other games, Natural Selection. I won't spoil anything major, but there is strong evidence that this game takes place in the same universe as the aforementioned game. The only thing I will spoil is that the ship you are on is shot down from orbit around the beautiful planet 4546B, and you get into the escape pod just in time. What happens next is up to you. The feeling of helplessness as you dive into the game on your first playthrough will stick with you forever. Beautifully crafted. 

I have written enough to make my case, at least I think so myself. There is a lot to the game, and I very much urge everyone reading this to get the game. It is worth every penny, and it is not the most expensive game. You get a lot of game for the money you spend, which is rare today

[h1] Best VR SciFi Title - Steap Learning Curve - Addictive [/h1]

Next to Elite Dangerous this is one of the best sci-fi exploration games I ever played in my life. Did not pay attention to this game for a while because I expected a diving sim. It's way more than that.

Play it on VR if you can! Best VR exploration game I played so far.

Similar to games like Green Hell.
10/10 would dive into this title again! 😉

I slept on this game for quite a while - my backlog was already saturated with more intensive survival games, and I could get my base building kicks elsewhere (seemingly with far more options). On the surface it looked like this game was a little boring, despite the great reviews.

Seems that I somehow missed that there is a compelling narrative here driving things along. This is a fantastic world to explore and find efficiencies within. You are in control over how much danger you want to put yourself in. Feel like chilling out and building a base? No problem. Keen to safely collect some resources towards your next project? Sure. Exploring the deep? Yikes! If you like.

I only wish there were a few more reasons to stay in this world a little longer, perhaps even a simple achievement such as scanning everything available?

An easy recommendation.

This is, without a doubt, my favorite game of all time. The vibe of this ocean world is just so pleasant, it's become the perfect place to go to get away from real life for me. Sure, there's drowning and sea monsters, but they're easier to deal with than rent and bills. Prevent the one, dodge the other. Simple. Life's real simple on the ocean world.

...also it's a great exploration survival game with a satisfying tech tree as you build up your ability to go farther and deeper to gather more unique resources to build your next upgrade, as you work your way not towards infinite growth or any sort of material wealth, but simply to make a way back home. Every new area you reach is fascinating and fun to explore, every new plant animal or mineral you see is well designed and fits well in an interconnected ecosystem, and the various smaller mysteries and optional discoveries spread around the planet are compelling and make for great replay content.

You should play Subnautica. Unless you've got like a crippling phobia of the deep sea or large things in the sea. In that case Subnautica might not be the game for you. But for everyone else, you should really play Subnautica. If you really like it, like I do, the sequel's good too.

One of the most unique survival exploration games out there. Literally nothing like it. The game is perfectly terrifying in every good way, the exploration and progression are amazing. You are only limited by how willing you are to go outside of your comfort zone. Creatures and world are full of beautiful scenes and terrifying sea monsters. 

Progression/Gameplay Loop 9/10 (can seem repetitive to some who are unfazed by the giant mf creatures) 

World 10/10 (tons of lore and story to be uncovered and pieced together but you will have to pay attention)

exploration 100000/10 (had to give it it's own section because it's the most notable part and game defining) 

graphics 10/10 (while it may lack in pure fidelity, the art style and beautiful scenes act in tandem to create some of the most colourful wondrous and mysterious areas i have seen in a game again it is truly unique and genuinely stunning 

is it buggy 8/10 (i did encounter some bugs but it was more to do with the physics of the game and how different things interact which i kinda expected considering 95% of the game is underwater, overall generally not that buggy) 

user friendly 8.5/10 (the game does a great job of telling you what to do and where to go if you want that. It also however rewards your own little self controlled expeditions to go out find resources and stray from the safe shallows, the reason i put it at an 8.5 is simply because i am a massive p**sy when it comes to this game and found myself not wanting to progress because i was too scared to venture out. which tbh might render it a higher score rather than a lower one but some people may just straight up give up with the game as whole because they don't want to continue) 

Sound design 11/10 (this game and it's squeal Below Zero hit the nail on the head with it's music and SFX. The smaller creatures feel mysterious yet friendly in a way but still alien, where as the large dangerous Leviathans feel imposing and terrifying, Side note I genuinely almost pissed myself when i heard the roar of the first reaper leviathan you bump in to and saw a giant red and grey snake with mandibles charging at me. anyways, the music is spot on and is likely my favourite soundtrack from any game or franchise for that matter ever, it makes the world feel filled to the brim with wonder, terror, mystery, calm and ultimately lived in by all the flora and fauna you encounter. 

overall rating 10/10 (if you're looking for a unique survival/kind of horror/exploration game that will bring you things you have never experienced before in all of your time gaming and that i can guarantee, then just play it. It's stunning and beautiful, Mysterious and Terrifying. 160763266.review:
Subnautica is a captivating masterpiece that submerges players into a rich and immersive underwater world teeming with wonder, mystery, and danger. Developed by Unknown Worlds Entertainment, this survival-adventure game offers an unparalleled experience that seamlessly blends exploration, crafting, and storytelling.

One of the most striking aspects of Subnautica is its breathtakingly beautiful underwater environment. From vibrant coral reefs to eerie deep-sea trenches, every corner of the ocean is meticulously crafted with stunning detail. The dynamic lighting effects and realistic water physics further enhance the sense of immersion, making every dive feel like a voyage into the unknown.

The gameplay mechanics of Subnautica are equally impressive. As the lone survivor of a crashed spaceship on an alien planet covered mostly by water, players must scavenge resources, build bases, and fend off hostile creatures to survive. The crafting system is intuitive yet deep, allowing players to construct a variety of tools, vehicles, and structures to aid in their exploration. Whether it's constructing a submarine to explore the depths or crafting a high-tech diving suit to withstand extreme pressures, the sense of progression and accomplishment is immensely satisfying.

However, what truly sets Subnautica apart is its masterful storytelling. Through environmental storytelling, audio logs, and cryptic messages scattered throughout the ocean floor, players gradually uncover the secrets of the planet and the fate of its previous inhabitants. The sense of mystery and discovery is palpable, driving players to delve deeper into the abyss in search of answers.

Moreover, Subnautica excels in creating a sense of tension and fear. The vastness of the ocean, coupled with the unknown dangers lurking in its depths, instills a constant sense of unease and anticipation. Whether it's the spine-chilling roar of a leviathan or the eerie darkness of an unexplored cave system, every moment is fraught with suspense, keeping players on the edge of their seats.

Beyond its captivating gameplay and storytelling, Subnautica also boasts exceptional attention to detail. From the intricate creature designs to the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, every aspect of the game is crafted with care and precision. The developers' passion for their creation shines through in every aspect, creating an experience that is truly unforgettable.

In conclusion, Subnautica is a triumph of game design that sets a new standard for the survival-adventure genre. With its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and immersive storytelling, it offers an unforgettable journey into the depths of the ocean. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or a newcomer to the genre, Subnautica is an absolute must-play that will leave you breathless in more ways than one. Dive in and discover the wonders that lie beneath the waves.

38930297.review:
It's hard to overstate what a magnificent exploration and adventure game Subnautica is.

What really stands out to me is that experience—not an XP bar, but the accumulation of knowledge about the game world, its locations, and its inhabitants—is the most powerful weapon in a player's arsenal.

Take Stalkers, for example: They're the first large predators a player will meet, and initially they're annoying and seem quite threatening. An experienced player will ignore them, though, or at most circle and poke them with a knife to make them go away, while at the same time stealing all of their scrap. It helps to have upgraded swim fins, upgraded O2, and other advantages, but if you took upgraded fins and O2 tanks away from experienced players, they still wouldn't have any issues with Stalkers.

There's a lot to find and a lot to do in this game. The need to unravel the game's central mysteries and to obtain blueprint fragments, salvage, and rare materials from wrecks, grottoes, and strange installations will force you to leave your comfort zone time and again. First you'll crawl out of the Safe Shallows, then you'll creep further and deeper, then you'll swim further still until one day you'll be amazed at how far away from Lifepod 5 you've gone, at the readout on your depth meter, and you'll wonder how you ever thought that the seaweed areas just outside of the Safe Shallows were in any way scary.

Sustenance is a challenge at first, and you'll scramble to get enough food and water, but later on they become a matter of management and planning ahead. If you're going on a long expedition, you'll want enough supplies to last for the duration, but not so many that you can't haul a goodly amount of salvage back to base.

As for fiddly stuff, you can spend hours building and customizing your underwater habitat, customize the look and module loadout of the various vehicles you can build (once you've got the complete blueprints and necessary materials), and have a lot of fun with the wide array of gadgets and Portal/Half-Life-style "techno-guns" the game has to offer. There's a lot of meat there, but the true meal lies in exploration.

Even at the very end of the game, though, armed with all the technology you've spent hours pulling out of wrecks and scanning (typically while watching your O2 meter like a hawk and listening nervously to that angry predator thrashing around outside), you'll never feel completely safe or at ease. There are great dangers lying in wait, and you'd better hope you spot them on your sonar before their sonar catches wind of you....

I used to be a SCUBA diver.  Can't do it anymore.   There are days when I miss it all so bad it hurts.  

The freedom.  The solitude.  The Unknown...    It's all out there, hidden beneath the waves. 

Subnautica is the game I have been waiting for.  In a strange way, it feeds the sea-hunger inside me somehow.  Can't quite explain this sensation without having it sound corny and contrived, but that's how it works for me.

I stumbled onto Subnautica purely by chance while browsing YouTube gaming clips.  Ever seen that *one* game that stops you dead in your tracks?  I did. Definitely got my attention, as I recall.  It was an Early Access release, so I could expect all kinds of unforeseen digital weirdness happening inside the game itself.  My PC's operating specs were a tad on the light side too, but it didn't matter.  I wanted that game.  Badly.

I bought it.  I played it.  I built things and survived. I enjoyed every minute that I spent 'underwater' again.    

It's an alien ocean on an alien world.  Curiously, the sights and sounds around you might seem strangely familiar, in spite of the bizarre shapes Life has taken in this place.  There is indescribable beauty to be found here, side by side with terrible dangers that are either innocently disguised or glaringly obvious.  It takes a certain mindset to fully appreciate this world,  as well as considerable restraint to avoid blindly lashing out at every shadow that flits past your facemask.      

Remember.  YOU are the intruder down there. 

Take a deep breath and immerse yourself completely.  

Welcome to Subnautica.

Everyone talks about how it's early access, bugs, blah blah blah. If you're reading this review, you know about all that. I recently realized I am a huge fan of survival sandbox games, and I have played quite a few in the last months.  Here is my personal impression of this one.

Graphics are incredible. I know everyone has said this, but it needs repeating. On the lowest settings, it still looks awesome! Some clipping and such, but it never really bothered me much.

It's very fluid (no pun intended) to get into it. I agree with most other reviews that recommend no using guides and such and just jump into the deep water (pun intended) and learn to swim on your own. It's a very friendly interface that gives just enough explanation to make you feel like you can do it on your own, but not enough to make it boring.

Edit: I forgot the most important part (to me at least.) The metabolism for food in this game is very nice. In plenty of other games like this you have to eat every two minutes or face death from starvation. In this game, keeping hydrated is the issue. While this is rather ironic while being surrounded by water, it makes a lot more sense. I get away with eating once every day or two depending on my activity. Dehydration keeps me drinking daily, but not constantly. Considering dehydration kills you faster than starvation, I feel this is the most realistic representation I have seen in one of these games thus far. 

Here is what any new player needs to know:

Expect it will hurt you until you prove to yourself that it can't. 
Explore. Even the dark and scary areas. They usually have the best loot.
Storage cubes cannot be used indoors (as of the writing of this review.)
Predators are everywhere and you are not one of them. If it can eat you, it will.
If it can eat you, it's usually in a scary area.
You WILL get snuck up on and jumpscared. 
Give it at least an hour before you start looking up stuff online, and once you do, do it very sparingly. Discovery is an awesome feature to this game and the more you have to figure out, the more valuable this game will be.

21312699.review:
After 41 hours, I feel like I'm ready to say my piece about this game.  It's important to specify that I'm playing in survival mode where you have to constantly worry about food and water.  The game will be very different depending on which mode you play, because in the sandbox mode you can freely build and explore without ever having to stop what you're doing to gather nourishment.  In hardcore, you have to be extra careful, because once you die you have to start over.  At this point, I'm glad I did not pick hardcore, because there are ways you can die that just aren't forseeable.  There also occasional bug in the game which results in your death, like the all too common diving reel malfunctions.

First Impressions:

This game is amazing.  That can be, and is, said about many games.  But there is nothing like Subnautica.  I had been waiting for 19 years, ever since playing the crap out of the incredibly immersive, fun, but ultimately flawed Sub Culture.  Finally, we have a game that surpasses Sub Culture in every aspect except the storyline.  With that said, Subnautica has flaws.

The Bad:

In all it's glory, there are a few nags, some of which make the game increasingly difficult as you get further into the game.  First, I'm going to get it out of the way that there is a startup bug that made me almost request a refund even before getting into the game. Subnautica doesn't always start, because the game menu screen frequently refuses to fully load.  This is probably some sort of GPU initialization issue that prevents the graphics from displaying properly.  In any event, I have to exit out of the game and restart it in Window mode to get the game to finish loading at all.

Also, The learning curve is very steep.  There are no instructions for anything, and the information given on any device in the crafting menus tell you nothing worthwhile about what stuff does.  There are some basic descriptions, but they're very poor.  For example the current generator says it generates current.  When I started playing I had no idea what I would want to create a current for.


The third thing is the max depth of the in game vehicles.  There is much debate about the actual depth of the game.  Some say it goes on forever.  Others have quoted that the game crashes out at 60,000 meters.  Some have said 20,000 meters.  Others have said there is a secret world in the greatest depths, which sounds pretty epic.  In any event.  The ocean goes deeper than I feel comfortable thinking about.  The problem here lies in the fact that the vehicles seem to have a max depth of 200 meters.  (I've since found the Cyclops can go to approximately 900 meters at the expense of power efficiency.  I believe the Seamoth can also go to a comparable depth.)

Fourth, the hunger and thirst meters drop far too quickly.  This seems nitpicky when you consider I did pick the survival mode, but the problem with this system is that you have to spend hunger and thirst to find food that becomes increasily more difficult to find as the game goes on.  As a result, you might find yourself spending almost half your time gathering food and supplies to make water.  Which leads me to the next problem in the game.

Fifth, scarcity of food and supplies for making water.  At first, everything is plentiful and readily available.  Salt, while a challenge to find when you don't know what you're looking for, seems to respawn readily and limitlessly.  Coral, while seemingly limitless at first, begins to disappear rapidly after many hours of gameplay.  Moreover, I have seen no indication that it respawns.  

Food, which pretty much comes from the natural fish stocks, can disappear amazingly fast from an area.  After 41 hours of gaming, I have effectively cleared all of the initial shallows of the ocean, plus the surrounding depths of fish.  It's amazing how fast they diminish.  The only solution seems to be to put respawning, or faster reproduction, of the fish in the game.  I have not seen any indication that the fish respawn at all, which seems clear by some of the dead zones I have in my current save.  There are some pretty heated debates about this in the discussion groups.  Naysayers claim the supplies are unlimited, and all you have to do is look further.  My answer to that is that you begin to spend a lot more thirst and food meter, energy, and other resources to find food.  

Because of this there is a rapidly diminishing return on the value of food and water in the game.  The devs claim it causes people to explore more.  I'm not satisfied with that response, because the reality is this:  if people have no motivation to explore.  If they just stick to the shallows and eat and drink, they aren't going to have the attention span to stick with the game for the long term anyway. Apparently, a fix is being tested in the experimental mode, but it's coming all too slow to a stable build.

Sixth, and my final gripe, and this is definitely as glaring as the fifth, scarcity of resources.  Copper, Quartz, Acid Mushrooms are plentiful at first, but become ridiculously difficult to come by as the game goes on.  Quartz is practically used in everything, because you need it for glass and rubber, which you need for building and making Power Cells to power your vehicles.  Each Power Cell takes a vast amount of resources, which would not be as much of a problem if they didn't deplete so rapidly.  Even with the power efficiency mod only a small expedition can use 6 power cells and leave you scrambling for resources.  Many users have defaulted to the same argument they have given to the food shortage problem, that there's plenty in the depths.  The problem is that it takes more and more energy, food, and water to farm this stuff.  You end up trapped in a cycle of more and more rapidly diminishing marginal utility on all of your resources.  This really needs to be fixed or users will basically be driven out of their own game by scarcity. 

Both of the last two problems have people vehemently defending the current scarcity, with the argument that resources are scarce in real life.  I would like to point out, however, that one person alone in a wilderness does not leave vast expanses of land void of any life.  Certainly these rich biomes should be able to support just one person.  Also, if the player were able to hunt for shellfish and crustaceans in the game, diversity of foods might help lower depletion rates.  The player should be able to find oysters and dig for clams.  

The Good:

Based on my criticisms, some might get the idea that I don't like the game.  That couldn't be more wrong.  Subnautica is, hands down, simply the best underwater game ever made.  There's no competition.  The environment is rich, full of wonder, and among the most immersive games I've ever played.  The world is packed full of fascinating creatures, beautiful vegetation, and unparalleled undersea effects.  The graphics are complimented by some of the most incredible sound you could possibly imagine.  All of it adds up to a game that makes you feel like you're living rather than playing.

It's one of those games that comes along and really changes things forever, at least among those who have played it.  In my opinion, the game hasn't gotten nearly the recognition it deserves.  The amount of stuff you can do in this game, and the painstaking attention to detail are mindblowing.  Those are things I hope never change with Subnautica.  Many early access games are dumbed down in later iterations.  Unknown Worlds Entertainment seems to have a good attitude about adding new features instead of taking them out, like some other developers of early access releases have done in the past.  I just hope they maintain the trend.

Subnautica is an oustanding game, worth its price about three times over.  It comes with my highest recommendation. In it's current state, I would give Subnautica a 9/10.

41830855.review:
I've never written a review for a game. I have a decent collection and there are more than a few I recommend to friends, but I've never bothered to take the time to sit down and describe exactly why I love or hate a game. I have very specific taste and telling people about all my little nitpicky problems always feels self-righteous at best and masturbatory at worst. 

So, when I tell you to drop whatever you're doing, block off a week from any and all social interaction, buy Subnautica and dive headfirst into it, I want you to understand my full meaning. 

Subnautica is a joy. It's what all survival games should aspire towards, and now that I'm on my third playthrough I can actually articulate what exactly it does right. And it does SO much right. From minute one, every action you take to further your survival gives you an actual, organic feeling of progression. Every piece of equipment you fabricate, every square meter you explore, every new thing you scan expands your capabilites and brings new opportunities and new challenges to light. Want to build that heat-resistant dive suit? You'll need benezine, for which you'll need to explore, for which you'll need a submersible, for which you need a power cell, on and on. Got the dive suit? Great, now you can build thermal plants to reliably charge your power cells. It's magnificent.

The survival mechanics aren't even the most interesting part. They're a framework upon which the rest of the game is built. The deeper you go, the more questions about the planet and its history arise. I won't spoil anything, but there's a number of truly great "oh shit" moments of the story that ask yet more questions and push you yet further and further into the deep. 

And it's presented beautifully. Small graphical issues aside, the look of the world is something like an underwater James Cameron wet dream (pun intended) and with each new biome you discover somewhere else to fall in love with. The soundtrack mixes perfectly with the world to underscore and enhance the game's wry humor, touching tragedy and genuine, pants-shitting terror. 

Oh yeah, it's scary too. The stakes feel absolutely real, and you'd better be prepared if you want to reach the end. Because there is an end. [i]They[/i] didn't reach it, but maybe you will.

Buy Subnautica. Play it, revel in it, and when you get to the end look back on when all you had was a busted lifepod and remember what you needed most. You'll know what I mean when you get there. Good luck.

38393495.review:
I pretty much agree with all the other positive comments, here, and have nothing really new to add, but I still want to express my extreme satisfaction with the game by offering a few helpful tips for beginners:

(equipment spoilers to follow -- NOT plot spoilers)

On conflict resolution...
[spoiler]This is not a "shooting game" per se.  Early on, you will need to think your way around hostile creatures.  Sure, a knife can ward things off for a moment, but you need to have a back up plan such as fleeing, or driving the creature away with subsequent attacks.  Note that it is possible to kill stuff, but it isn't really necessary.  I wouldn't be surpised if you can go the whole game without killing anything, really; even food.  Aside, later on you can consider grappling on with your Prawn, and using your mining arm attachment to "drill" a hostile creature.  Underwater rodeo!
[/spoiler]

On being prepared
[spoiler]Always bring an extra bottle or two of water.  Don't know what it is about this game, but you get thirsty pretty fast.  Later on, farming Melons is a great way to manage hunger and thirst in one convenient food.  You can even have a farm on the Cyclops!
[/spoiler]

On navigation...
[spoiler]If you want as few spoilers as possible for mapping, or you just like to explore at your own pace, you should consider creating your own navigational buoys/beacons.  In addition to really important locations, I personally created three solely for triangulation.  One near your life pod.  One precisely 1000m to the north at the surface.  And one precisely 1000m to the west.  Then, swimming at the surface above every interesting landmark/resource/point of interest, I would record the distance to each beacon with a pencil/notepad.  Now, if you wanted to make your own map, you would open up a graphic editor app such as SketchUp, and draw your center beacon, followed by your north and your west beacons.  (all 1000m apart, remember?)  Now here is the magic part.  Draw a circle from each corresponding buoy with a radius equal to the distance you wrote down.  three circles; one from each beacon; radius = range in meters.  See that intersection?  Congratz, you just triangulated the position of that point of interest, relative to your navigation beacons!
[/spoiler]

On virtual reality...
[spoiler]If you have an Oculus Rift or a Vive, then, you really do owe it to yourself to give this game a shot.  Darting through coral reefs, looking around corners, catching a glimpse of creatures that could eat you in a single bite... These are the experiences that literally take our breath away!  You will not be disappointed.  It should be noted that some may consider this a moderate-to-extreme VR experience.  If you need to blow the dust off your headset then you might want to work up your tolerance again about an hour or two per day for a week to get back in the saddle.  Some dry-eye, too.  Probably a "VR comfort" experience comparable to The Solus Project (another game that I highly recommend).
[/spoiler]

On Base location...
[spoiler]You cannot go wrong with base placement, really.  Just pick the place with the nicest view.  I chose the Kelp forest because I could sit there and stare at my monitor for minutes at a time (literally, yes I have no life! ha) watching the kelp wave in the current, with the glitter of the surface wave, above, and little schools of fish playing amongst the various flora and crevices.  Peaceful.
On another note of utility, I also created two type of other bases:  recon and outpost.  Recon bases would be small, self-sustained two room setups in remote locations consisting of some food/water supplies such as a melon farm as noted above, and a sonar room.  This would be used to filter/search for specific resources such as copper and magnetite that would link with my HUD and add waypoints to help me find them.
Secondly, the outposts would be remote locations with rechargers for batteries and power cells, and farms.  Some crafting station and storage, too.  Just a way of resupplying when away from home.
[/spoiler]

On resource scarcity / respawn...
[spoiler]There is NOOOOO need to worry about a lack of resources or respawn.  Seriously.  I see this question pop up enough, but the game world is filled TO THE BRIM with more resources than any sane person should need.  I even think some, like titanium, spawn ocassionally in the form of debris from the Aurora wreckage.  You will not run out of anything.  It might be a little burdensome to actually get out and explore to find more stuff, but you will find it.  Just go with the flow, and push those boundaries!  The game's beauty is worth pushing past your comfort zones.  And don't worry so much about getting eaten alive.  Save often, and take risks!  That's part of the fun :)  The deep, dark, noisy depths of this game aren't nearly as terrifying as your mind will make it out to be.  Sure there are some dangers, but you learn really quickly what you can get away with, and when to keep looking over your shoulder. (blubablubablub)  Hint: The ocean is usually a noisy place; it's when it gets really quiet that you need to.... SWIM!! :D
[/spoiler]

Obligatory word on Early Access:  despite being EA, the game is basically complete as far as I'm concerned.  I have completed the game 99%, or just short of [spoiler] the final step of leaving the planet [/spoiler] with no show-stopper technical issues.  Basically bug-free with some minor glitches that can be avoided as long as you save often: a sensible mantra for any gamer these days.  I could be wrong, or plans may change, but I believe they are planning 1.0 release in the first month or two of 2018, so at this point, as far as I'm concerned, they focusing on optimization and polish, and YES, they are still VERY active in the community.  I'm looking forward to supporting their next project.

So, there you have it.  The game is worth the ~$25US that they are asking for it.  The game is worth your time, too.  Having completed 99% of the game as noted above, I feel like my sense of adventure has been satisfied for a great while, and I plan to come back for a speed run or two after official release.  125 hours, so far.  You can't get that kind of utility from going to the movies, or going to the bar.  This game is WORTH it and more!

45487662.review:
One of the best games I ever played.

First words that comes to my mind are "deep immersion". Developers created a huge, beautiful and very realistic world. Subnautica is mainly focused on exploration and it is extremely good. In fact, I think that there are no enemies in this game; at least, I could not perceive any creature as enemy. They are not monsters but just local fauna that live their life, in fact they are not even aliens, they are at home and you were not invited. There is only one alien on whole planet and this alien is you. Once you learn behaviour of animals you will very rarely encounter any aggression. If for some reason you want to fight... well, you may find a prey, but bloodshed is absolutely senseless and unnecessary.

Game is quite peaceful but it does not mean that there are no dangers in ocean. Pressure, lack of oxygen, cramped caves, limited light... deeper and deeper you went, more and more awe you feel. When your submarine hangs over the abyss and you can see nothing but endless cliff and depth... it is scary... well, I hardly can remember another game that gave me such intense emotions.

World in Subnautica is opened for exploration, from the very start you can travel... well, everywhere. Still, amount of accessable locations is cleverly limited by available technologies. You can try to explore deep caves immediately after planetfall but without supply of oxygen you will just drown. So game softly push player to explore safe shallows first.

There is storyline and in my opinion it is very good. I do not want to spoil anything - just want to say that storyline is simple but intense, yet not intrusive in same time. Bit by bit you will visit all locations and learn all mysteries. Final scene gave me very complex and positive emotions - it is beautiful and full of hope with light sadness. It was worth all long way down.

Gameplay can be divided into two stages. During first stage you salvage technologies, gather resources and craft equipment. There is some grind but I can not say it is boring or tedious... you just explore surroundings and study local life, gathering useful items by the way. And second stage is travelling - when you gathered enough resources and crafted basic vehicle - Seamoth - you can explore almost everywhere. There are only three vehicles in game - not too much, but they are widely customisable. You can install different modules - extra armor, torpedo launchers, defensive electric field and so on, also it is available to change appearance of vehicle, such as colour and, finally, you can even give your vehicle a name.

You can construct your base that will serve as center of operations. Constructing is simple and effective, it is very easy to learn and comfortable to use. There are lot of different modules you can combine and create your awesome station. Even more importantly, game offers a lot of different furniture and decorations to customise your base and turn it to... well, not just "a base" but your home. I really got attached to my tiny but comfortable underwater apartments and my tamed cuddlefish. I really hope that my pets will survive without me... wait, it is just a game... *sigh*.

Of course, I must mention the stunning beauty of Subnautica. Blazing sunsets, dense kelp forests, impenetrable darkness with sparkles of luminescente flora and fauna... almost every scene literally craves for screenshot. As for sounds and music - they are excellent, such quality is really impressive. For example, I humbly advise you to search for "Tropical Eden" melody, it creates amazing magical atmosphere I was truly enchanted with.

Game is not perfect, there are some bugs. Several times I seen fish swimming in my base. Once, during exploration of Aurora wreck, I got stuck in textures and then suddenly fell out of the world. Well... all this tiny confusing troubles seems insignificant for me.

Probably the best advice I can give - do not watch videos and do not read guides. Explore by yourself! Believe me, pleasure from discovering new things is worth the time. If you love adventure games with main focus on exploration - Subnautica is a sure bet. Honestly, I do not know any games that can compete with Subnautica in this niche. 

You do not want to miss this game.

119029302.review:
[h1]Subnautica [b]knows[/b] how to make you uncomfortable and it does so perfectly.[/h1]

On my first night I played 2 hours before I had to go to bed. The second day was a free day for me and I ended up playing for 12 hours in one sitting. The last time I had played a single game for 12 hours straight was maybe three years ago!


I actually don't enjoy Survival games that much. Base building and meaningless crafting isn't really a selling point for me, however Subnautica isn't a simple survival game, it's an [b]exploration game with horror[/b]. Yes, you're gathering materials and crafting stuff, but it's all being used to progress the game; To make better tools and equipment to let you dive deeper into the ocean's void and reach that distress signal at the ocean floor.

Yes you can make a fully fledged base that houses everything you could ever need, but you could also just make 2 rooms to house all the tools and storage you need. It will still be sufficient. So you're free to decide how much base building you want to do.


During exploration you'll first be scared to take a 90m dive inside the hole in the ground you just found. You don't know what's down there, or if you'll even make it out of the hole itself.
As time goes on you'll find yourself making it to 150, 200, 300 and further depths, but the catch is that [b]you never stop being afraid[/b]!


That's the thing about this game, you always need to go deeper. The secrets of the world aren't just scattered across the surface for you to find. You need to head for the depths and that's where it gets scary. The deeper you go, the further you are from the surface. The world won't be the sunny shallows where all the cute fish are anymore, no. You're now in the depths. You're either in an underwater labyrinth of tunnels, far away from a straight swim to the surface, or you're in the middle of dark open waters where anything can come for you from any direction.


In this game, no matter how much you progress, you'll always feel scared. It's f*cking terrifying, but also addictive! You're scared $hitless at the depth you are, but you can't wait to improve your equipment so that you can go even deeper than what you just dared. To meet whatever else lies in the void.



The Graphics are beautiful. You'd think the cartoonish looks would take away from the experience, but they don't. It's beautiful when it wants to be and terrifying when it needs to. It also has amazing and almost photo-realistic lighting in water which really captures that feeling of being underwater. So yeah, you know those underwater videos of people swimming in open waters where every direction they look, the water slowly fades to an opaque darkness where you have no idea if something's in the water with them? You're gonna be seeing that here and you WILL be diving in it. If you didn't already have thalassophobia, [b]you will[/b] after this game.



The setting of the game makes for a unique gameplay, but it doesn't end there. The designers didn't just think that the setting alone would make up for a good game. No, they knew they had to put in work and they did. They created an experience that you [b]cannot get anywhere else[/b]. They also knew how to design their greatest weapon: The atmosphere.

Truly the game's atmosphere is it's best feature and you will only beg for more while sitting in your soiled pants.


To be honest I can't fully describe the amazing atmosphere this game creates. I can't compare it to anything else. Maybe [b]Iron Lung[/b] but that only covers a fraction of what this has to offer. All I can say is that it's immersive and terrifying. For people like myself who don't enjoy having a character who talks BS every minute, I'm glad to inform you that your character doesn't talk, which greatly helps immerse you in the game, although you will still hear his screams of agony when being eaten alive at 500m depth.



The Story is told through Logs found in wrecks and events happening in front of you. Some logs contain Text while others have recorded Voice. Voice acting is good, doesn't get cringy and doesn't try to be over dramatic when there is no reason to. It feels real.

Your only "companion" is your PDA's onboard AI which does drop in to give you information from time to time, but not at all close to being an annoying voice in your head. Never. In fact, since it is just an AI, it talks like a machine rather than a human and at times the information it gives you is information you'd rather not know.
How? Let's give an example for real life: You're in a pitch black jungle and can't see $hit. Well, you can probably go to sleep and wait out the night until morning, right? But what if you are then notified that you're not alone? That in fact, you are being watched right now? How would that make you feel?



A very fun system is the Time Capsules. When players finish the game, they can leave a Time Capsule behind with a few items inside (with limitations), along with a message and photo. Other players can find these capsules in their world and use the contents. These can be very fun to find. For example, two of the crucial tools I needed, I happened to find just at the right time in a capsule. Truly a lucky find, especially since other players instead had to complete the blueprints to make it.



[h1]Alright, time to stop kissing a*s[/h1]
What are the negatives? No game is perfect right?

Well if you didn't have thalassophobia, you do now! :))


Okay jokes aside, here are the issues you [u]might[/u] face:

This is an exploration game. Most things are not marked on the UI for you to follow. You need to actually explore to find most things. Blueprints are one of these.

You don't know how to craft everything from the start. You need to search through wrecks for  blueprints to learn how to craft the item. It's a good system, but because of the exploration needed, one player might find a blueprint on their first try while others spend hours searching for the same fragment.

Of course you can build a Scanner Room which helps you find what you're looking for in that area, but I personally didn't bother to make it before I was 80% done with the game. I also didn't unlock two blueprints even after finishing the game.  You can always check the Wiki to get what you want but this is what playing Vanilla will be like.


Story Locations: 
Much like the Blueprint Fragments, you need to explore the ocean and find some of these locations yourself which means the same problem can occur where you might have a hard time finding the desired location. For me this went smoothly and I don't think it's as troublesome as the Blueprints.



[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Yes, I absolutely recommend this game. I'm not one who is easily impressed (you can check my other reviews and see for yourself) but this game is one of the few that I not only recommend but will regard as one of the best and unique experiences I had!

This game brings fresh new things for you to experience that you just can't find anywhere else. The amount of positive reviews given for this game are well-earned.

If you want to know how many hours of gameplay you're gonna get out of this, I can tell you how long it took me to finish it:
By building a major base and two small outposts, exploring [b]most of the map[/b] (not every bit and cranny), using [b]little[/b] help from Wiki here and there, and doing everything I found fun, it took me around 49 hours to finish the game. Of course you could use the Wiki or just be REALLY LUCKY and finish quicker, or you can f*ck around even more than I did and end up with an even longer playtime!

Whatever the case, for me, it was well worth the money.

Before I'll let you know about my honest opinion of this game I'd like to point out that I'm normally quite picky about open world survival games, and most of them bore me really quick, but this one doesn't, particularly because it has a few special features. Also I'm not a native english speaker:

Can not recommend more. 

I usually HATE survival crafting games, mainly because there isn't usually any point to what you're doing except "build more stuff so you can have more stuff to build more stuff" in a never-ending cycle not going anywhere.

But Subnautica surprised me by having an actual story that is gradually unlocked through exploration and crafting items that allow you to travel deeper into the darkest depths to progress the story, actually giving a sense of purpose to the crafting element. I found the story very engaging in the way it was presented and it gives you a real sense of accomplishment when you progress as it's not just handed to you straight off the bat.

For those of you like me, who have a phobia of deep, natural water, you will find this game to be quite scary at times, with it's monsters lurking in the deep, especially if you get stuck out in the middle of a particularly deep biome at night, but it's a kind of intriguing fear that makes you want to progress further so you can go down to where the monsters are to see what's actually down there. The game gives you a constant drive to move deeper and deeper to uncover the mysteries.

The graphics are beautiful, the world is hostile and believable but the AI is a bit simple and a few times I had a few of the larger monsters basically stuck at the surface with their head above the water not able to go anywhere.

It's a fantastic game with organic exploration, mystery and intrigue throughout and I would recommend it to anyone, even if you're not a fan of survival crafting games.

Tip: don't look up any info about this game beforehand, it's much more interesting to go into it completely blind.
